-----Original Message-----
From: Kris Estrada [mailto:Kris_Estrada at sjusd.org] 
Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2007 8:59 AM
To: Jim Bojorquez; Patricia Sepulveda; Patti Vongsa
Subject: Fwd(2): virus warning

Good Morning Friends,

I haven't read the news yet, or listened to the radio to hear about this
reported virus, but just in case:

Michael, do you have a disk I could borrow to run anti-virus on my
school computer.....I know it is infected in the Microsoft suite.

Thanks and a hug to each of you,

Mary 


Anyone-using Internet mail such as Yahoo, Hotmail, AOL and so on. 

This information arrived this morning, Direct from both Microsoft and
Norton. 

Please send it to everybody you know who has access to the Internet. 

You may receive an apparently harmless e-mail with a Power Point 
presentation ' Life is Beautiful '

If you receive it DO NOT OPEN THE FILE UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE S, 
and delete it immediately.

If you open this file, a message will appear on your screen saying: 

'It is too late now, your life is no longer beautiful.' 

Subsequently you will LOSE EVERYTHING IN YOUR PC, and the person who
sent it to you will gain access to your name, e-mail and password. 

This is a new virus which started to circulate on Saturday afternoon. 

AOL has already confirmed the severity, and the anti virus software's
are not capable of destroying it.

The virus has been created by a hacker who calls himself 'life owner.' 

PLEASE SEND A COPY OF TH IS E-MAIL TO ALL YOUR FRIENDS, and ask them to
PASS IT ON IMMEDIATELY!

From tursi at harmlesslion.com  Fri Nov 30 11:35:16 2007
From: tursi at harmlesslion.com (tursi)
Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 08:35:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: FL: Fwd: Fwd(2): virus warning
In-Reply-To: <E6B6E66F148F4EB4AAA1DBB0F64BF30C@foxtron>
References: <00AE44BC9CFA9D4BB256656ACD8EF79F01B37DBC@cuhsd-ex2003.cuhsd-int.prv><8CA00CB52889484-AC8-A98@webmail-me17.sysops.aol.com><c9a8951e0711291241x63e6a4a8kb494ae6988dd0e2d@mail.gmail.com>
	<C2CECD2A42254A508B5F643AC177E345@DualCorePC>
	<E6B6E66F148F4EB4AAA1DBB0F64BF30C@foxtron>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0711300805580.12280@localhost.localdomain>

> Agreed. Better safe than sorry and not everyone is at same level of 
> internet savvy, and hey it only uses 4KB of bandwidth but everyone 
> moaning about it used nearly 100kb ;)

There's no intention to be mean about it on most people's side, but the 
forwarding of these fake email virus warnings causes unnecessary concern, 
miseducation and, in the days before spam was a big deal, were considered 
major drains on limited network traffic.

The fact is that education is always better than "better safe than sorry". 
It's more than okay to make a mistake, the point is to learn from it.

There are a few key phrases that pretty much all the social viruses (so 
called because they spread only by convincing people to pass them on) 
contain.

The biggest giveaway tends to be the encouragement to send copies to 
everyone you know! Seeing that is usually a good sign that you should 
investigate further before taking action.

Generic greetings like the "good morning friends" in this one is a good 
indicator.

Almost all of them include a phrase like "this information came directly 
from [insert big official sounding names here]". The FCC is often cited 
which is a dead giveaway since the FCC doesn't issue virus warnings. This 
one didn't have that at least. If you aren't certain, it's pretty easy to 
visit the sites of the companies listed (Microsoft, AOL, etc) and check 
for any warnings.

This sort of thing has been around as long as electronic communications. 
If you're interested in history of the email variants, do a web search on 
the classic "GoodTimes Virus".

Unfortunately the internet is a dangerous place today. These were once 
just mildly annoying experiments in human behaviour, and mere jokes. Today 
the lessons learned are actively used by criminals to coerce people to 
install and spread malware. Even if you don't have anything on your 
computer that seems valuable to you, every machine on the net is useful to 
them - if they can get into it. I would urge anyone using the internet to 
educate themselves - to not do so is a disservice to yourself and others.



From rwelles at gmail.com  Fri Nov 30 14:11:18 2007
From: rwelles at gmail.com (Knux The Fox)
Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 13:11:18 -0600
Subject: FL: Fwd: Fwd(2): virus warning
Message-ID: <c7e4f15f0711301111v3fb7463cj35a6c7820c6109e2@mail.gmail.com>

There are a few good rules of thumb when dealing with these issues.  If it
sounds suspect, then it is.  If the email address the email is coming from
sounds spammy, and/or is not a member of your friends or family, it's
probably fake.  Also, most email hosts, including Hotmail, Yahoo, Gmail,
MSN, and many others offer free email virus scanning.  If you're worried
about viruses, get a good antivirus.  Among the best free antiviruses are
AVG and Antivir.  There are also several good pay antiviruses, like McAfee,
Norton, and recently voted the best, Kaspersky.  Just be careful with those,
since they tend to want to block off things that aren't viruses, like games
that connect to the internet, chat clients, and sometimes even Microsoft
apps.  I've used them all.  Currently, I use the free AVG Personal Antivirus
aka AVG Free Edition.  Like many have said.  A little education saves face,
and saves grief.

From santafox at comcast.net  Fri Nov 30 14:30:58 2007
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 19:30:58 +0000
Subject: FL: FWA Furry Variety Show: We Want You!
Message-ID: <113020071930.3510.475064F20006CD8600000DB622007601809801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

Believe it or not, FWA is less than three months away now, and that time is going to fly by with all of the winter holidays coming up. So, that means it's time to start thinking up ideas for the third annual Furry Weekend Atlanta Furry Variety Show!

To make it easier for interested performers to find other performers for acts, or to just bounce ideas around without making them completely public, I've set up a mailing list for FVS planning:

  http://groups.google.com/group/fwa-fvs

If you are coming to FWA and want to be in the show, just go to that page and request membership, and I'll approve you as quickly as I can. Details on the show and guidelines for variety show acts can be found here:

  http://www.furryweekend.com/varietyshow

I would like to get notice of any planned acts as early as possible, so if you're planning something, please join the mailing list and post your ideas there. If you really want to keep your idea top-secret, just send your information directly to me as soon as you have it ready.

Thanks and Cheers,
Santa Fox
FWA Furry Variety Show & Fursuiting and Pawpetry Track Director

Santa Fox's Den - http://www.jinglefox.com/

From minnieme4rl at aol.com  Fri Nov 30 17:50:51 2007
From: minnieme4rl at aol.com (minnieme4rl at aol.com)
Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 17:50:51 -0500
Subject: FL: Apology for Virus Warning Post
Message-ID: <8CA01BA976AAAB2-149C-27E9@MBLK-M35.sysops.aol.com>

I would like to take this opportunity to formally apologize to everyone on these lists for sending out the virus warning.? I am a high school teacher, not in the high tech industry.? This e-mail was forwarded to everyone in my district.? Usually stuff like that gets in the spam filter, but this one didn't, so I thought it was quite urgent.? I don't keep up with virus warnings since I use Macs.? But I do have a PC at school.

I sincerely apologize if I offended or irritated anyone.? I will permanently butt out of any computer affairs and leave it to the experts.? I was just trying to help, but I ended up pissing off more people, so again, I'm very, very sorry and I promise that it will never happen again.? I have learned my lesson.

Minnie

Seen'  Section (http://baarsden.itgo.com/seen.html).  Check them out!

From santafox at comcast.net  Fri Dec  7 16:39:39 2007
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Fri, 07 Dec 2007 21:39:39 +0000
Subject: FL: Fursuiting Wiki Updates
Message-ID: <120720072139.9729.4759BD9B0003E8E30000260122092299279801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

I just spent some quality time updating the Performance section of the fursuiting Wiki:

  http://fursuit.org/wiki/doku.php?id=fursuit:performance

After sorting through it all, I found that there's still a lot of holes and a lot of things about performance that could be said but haven't been said.  I've contributed to some areas, but I can't do it all by myself.

Remember that if you are on this mailing list, you can log into the Wiki and make updates.  If you have useful information to share about fursuits and fursuiting (building, performance, or other related topics) and it's not already in the Wiki, please consider contributing so that everyone can benefit.  If you've forgotten how to access the Wiki for editing, just go to the 'FURSUIT member private web page' link on the main www.fursuit.org page, and follow the link that reads "Chick Here to Log into the Wiki to edit it".  You'll need your fursuit mailing list email address and password to login.

If you want to contribute, but just aren't the Wiki type, please don't let that stop you.  Send me your contributions off-list, and I'll happily Wikify them for you and put them into the right sections.  This Wiki is a already good resource, but with a little proper care and feeding, it can become a really great resource for everyone :-)

Thanks and Cheers,
Santa Fox

--
Santa Fox's Den - http://www.jinglefox.com/

well to be honest the wwgfd (what would gorman freeman do) comes from a
glorious game called half life.  it's an fps with a crazy physicis engine
and the first weapon you ever get...is a crowbar.   so basicly the question
is, "what would gorman freeman hit in the face with a crowbar?" :P so i'm
putting down the ppl who try and set fursuiters on fire (btw i've been one
of thsoe fursuiters.  and thankgod i knew the person..ex friend of mine...
acuse well he tried it, and well if you ever wanted to see a large kangaroo
nail some one hard in the crotch...well there you had it.  he had to go to
the hospital and get stitches.   i wasn't even kind enough to give him a
ride there, i was totaly fet up and now there's a restraining order ^.^)

> . But on a more serious note, I truly find those who put down fursuiters =

I have found that horses and asses react alright for the most part. All you
have to do is give them time to get use to the idea that your not a threat.
Equines are quite qureas and will not take to long to want to see what the
fursuit is. All you need is space and time. Like all animals if you go right
up to them they will think of you as a treat and will try to run away or if
they cant do that they will attack

From francisco-sender-6f5fe9 at vulpes.net  Sat Dec 22 18:53:26 2007
From: francisco-sender-6f5fe9 at vulpes.net (Francisco Azinsan)
Date: Sat, 22 Dec 2007 17:53:26 -0600
Subject: FL: FC2008 December Newsletter
Message-ID: <20071222235326.GA55203@critter.net>


Countdown to the big event: We are just weeks away from Further Confusion
2008, as such, each newsletter gets more important. This will be one of the
last news letters to go out before the big event.

In this month's issue
1.  Come and work for FC!
2.  Pre-Registration closes in just a few days!
3.  Dealer Room Information
4.  Furry Night Live 2008 approaches quickly!
5.  Furly Edition
6.  Fursuit Badging at FC2008
7.  Schedule of Important Times for FC2008
8.  Final Newsletter
9.  Next Public Meeting


1.  Come and work for FC!

Want to meet more people at FC this year? Want to save some money?

Yes. You can do both by joining convention staff this year. We still have a
number of open positions available. Please visit the FC page at
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2008/about/hiring>

If interested, please contact hr at furtherconfusion.org for consideration. If
you have additional talents to offer which are not listed there, contact us
anyway! We just might put your talents to good use!


2.  Pre-Registration closes in just a few days!

Pre-registration closes on December 30th at 11:59pm, so don't delay if you
haven't registered yet. Mail-in forms should be postmarked by December 30th as
well, to give us time to get things entered. All updates and changes need to
be received no later than January 5th, 2008.

Single-day memberships can be purchased at the convention - they are not
available through pre-registration.

Single day prices are:
   Thursday only $20
   Friday only $25
   Saturday only $30
   Sunday only $25
   Monday only $20


3.  Dealer Room Information

- Furry Market Place sales are now fully closed. All spaces that will be sold
have been sold. There are no further Furry Market Place spaces to be had.

- Applications for the Dealer Room/Furry Market Place WAITING LIST will be
accepted through December 25th, 2007. If you want on the waiting list for a
last minute chance at getting into the room, go to the Dealer page on the
website, download the Waiting List form, print it, fill it out, and send it to
us. Get it postmarked no later than Christmas and we will put the form on file
for a chance if there are any cancellations. Please include a e-mail address
you check OFTEN as that is the only way we will contact you if a space becomes
available for you.

- We are mailing out Dealer Room and Furry Market Place confirmation packets
via standard postal mail (NOT E-mail) on Friday December 21st, 2007. We will
also post a copy of the items that are being sent out in that mailing, except
for the 1 sheet containing the specific confirmations, to the website sometime
after Christmas. So if your POSTAL MAILING address has changed since you
signed up for your table/space, be sure to check back to the Dealer page on
the website for the information from the mailing.


4.  Furry Night Live 2008 approaches quickly!

FC's Sunday evening stage show features a variety of furry acts performed
live, plus short video segments, with cash prizes decided on audience ballot.
We will be shooting for a rough lineup by mid-January, and space is limited.
Please reserve a slot by sending email to fnl at furtherconfusion.org with:

- Title of your act
- Main Contact's name/email
- Approximate running time
- Act is for competition (yes/no)
- Any special requirements beyond plain CD/DVD playback: live audio,
  instruments, or other custom audio sources.

Be sure to contact us soon as the show may fill up. Don't wait for FC itself!

For further announcements, plus full participation forms and at-con FNL
schedule to be posted soon, sign up for FNL08 discussion mailing list at
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2008/signup/fnl>

We are also seeking intrepid souls who are organized, punctual and silent to
fill our Stage Ninja Dojo. Please contact us at fnl at furtherconfusion.org -
First comers to receive Ninja Kitty Hats courtesy of BunnyWarez.com at the
show!


5.  Furly Edition

Party Announcements, Other items of interest that should go in the first
edition? The deadline to get submissions in for inclusion within Furly Edition
Zero is midnight on the evening of January 16th. Due to the time required for
preparation and printing no submissions can be accepted after that time. If
you have specific announcements to put within Furly Zero for the beginning of
the con, send them in to marketing at furtherconfusion.org. If you have
announcements for later printings of Furly Edition, we will have boxes put out
at the con at con-ops and the info desk.


6.  Fursuit Badging at FC2008

If you have a fursuit, are pre-registered, and need a fursuit badge, here's
what to do. Before January 1, 2008, send a picture of your fursuit to
fursuit-badges at furtherconfusion.org and include the following information in
the email:

- Your real name
- The fursuit name
- Your registration confirmation number

The file can be any standard picture format (JPEG, PNG, TIFF, etc.) at 300 dpi
with a usable area of 450 by 600 pixels.

The first fursuit badge is free (though a donation to the convention would be
appreciated), while subsequent badges are $5 each.

Photographs for fursuit badges will also be taken at the convention. Please
see the times that will be posted at the Registration Desk for the hours this
will be offered.


7.  Schedule of Important Times for FC2008

These times are, of course, subject to change, especially on the Thursday
times where we will be in mid-setup.

For a listing of all these times, please see our Hours of Operation page at
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2008/events/hours>


8.  Final Newsletter

We'll be sending out on final newsletter in mid January but it will
necessarily be short. Happy Holidays to everyone from our family to yours.


9.  Next Public Meeting

Our next staff meeting will be January 5th starting at noon in the San
Jose Doubletree. Come be part of something great and volunteer. Look at
any LCD screen for "Further Confusion..." to see what meeting room we are
in.

-- 
Further Confusion
info at furtherconfusion.org
http://www.furtherconfusion.org/

From marcwolf at marcwolf.org  Mon Dec 24 19:27:16 2007
From: marcwolf at marcwolf.org (David Boccabella)
Date: Tue, 25 Dec 2007 10:27:16 +1000
Subject: FL: Idea's for projects
In-Reply-To: <20071222235326.GA55203@critter.net>
Message-ID: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOICEJIFIAA.marcwolf@marcwolf.org>


Hi Folks
I have not posted for a while due to work.

Anyway - for some of the more technical furs I have a couple of idea's

One of the problems  of wearing a fursuit and wanting to put animatronics
into it is controlling them. With professional special effects companies you
can have teams of people with remote control units activating the servo's.
But if your are one person then it becomes much more difficult. Especially
when trying to act in the suit as well.

One possibility is voice recgonition. There are sever small self contained
kits out there. I have found this one
http://www.active-robots.com/products/accessories/speech.shtml which can
handle 20 to 40 words.

The codes relating to these words are send output via an serial port.

The words you use do NOT have to me real words. You can program whines,
growls, snorts and any other 'sound' you want and the system can be taught
to recognise them.

I have mentioned PicAXE's before. These are brilliant little chip that you
can program in BASIC. They have a lot of instructions for handling Servo's
and Stepping motors, as well as a lot of other I/O functionality.

This is great for working with upto 4 or 5 servo's.

If you want  more then there is this fellow..
http://www.robotshop.ca/home/suppliers/devantech-en/devantech-sd21-servo-con
troller.html  This can controll upto 21 servo's.  One very nice feature is
that you can set it to move a servo from point A to B in X milliseconds.
This will take a lot of load off programming various sequences etc.

To use it you can drop in either a BASIC-Stamp, or a 18X PicAXE and it will
run happily using the I2C bus.  Addin memory is easy as you can wire up
serial EEPROMS.

Programming concepts.

What I was thinking of was this - setting up the memory as a continious bank
from 0 to XXXX.  The first 20 locations are set as jump points to the
sequences.

i.e.

Position 1 = 256  = From Locatin 256 is the seguence for command 1.

With care and control bytes you can do a lot including a psuedo language for
loops, pauses, etc. The rest is your imagination.

I hope some of my idea's will give folks a way to solve problems etc.

Take Car

Dave a.k.a. Marcwolf
No virus found in this outgoing message.
Checked by AVG Free Edition.
Version: 7.5.516 / Virus Database: 269.17.8/1195 - Release Date: 24/12/2007
11:19


From bob at ginkosoft.com  Wed Dec 26 18:31:49 2007
From: bob at ginkosoft.com (Bob Bauhaus)
Date: Wed, 26 Dec 2007 15:31:49 -0800
Subject: FL: Idea's for projects
In-Reply-To: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOICEJIFIAA.marcwolf@marcwolf.org>
References: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOICEJIFIAA.marcwolf@marcwolf.org>
	<1198609925.3B5ABE42@dj11.dngr.org>
	<1198614706.40C3887@fe8.dngr.org>
	<1198711913.34AF5296@fd9.dngr.org>
Message-ID: <1198711914.757AAEE@ff2.dngr.org>

> One of the problems  of wearing a fursuit and wanting to put 
> animatronics
> into it is controlling them.

(BTW, first time posting, and love your website, Marcwolf)

Has anyone tried something somewhat automatic, where you don't have to 
conciously control them? I remember you mentioned a tail that swayed, 
but I'm thinking for head controls. For example, with a 6 
degree-of-freedom sudden motion sensor (like what's in the wii remote 
and some laptops) installed in the head, you could tell head movement 
control the eyes with it.

A sudden turn to the left or right typically implies looking in that 
direction, so the character's eyes moving that way would be natural. 
Similarly, looking up for wider eyes, looking down for closed eyes.

Another control would be small cheap microphones, one in each costume 
ear. Not only for improved hearing in costume but polling at even 1kHz 
would be enough to determine noise level.

If things are louder to the left, the left ear could swivel as if trying 
to hear. If things are louder to the right, the right ear could swivel 
instead. If there's a loud sound in general, both ears could swivel back 
and flattened.

Also, any thoughts on the arduino ( www.arduino.cc )?

--BobCoon

Hello Bob,

I've seen what you describe already, animitronics that are pre-programmed. Ears that move towards sounds, tails that wag by themselves, or when you walk, eyes that bink and move... it's been done... but couldn't tell you who did them - maybe someone else can on this list.

-Kody Wolf

From tsuyoto at gmail.com  Fri Dec 28 13:02:22 2007
From: tsuyoto at gmail.com (Tsuyoto Wolf)
Date: Fri, 28 Dec 2007 10:02:22 -0800
Subject: FL: Balaclava question
In-Reply-To: <BAY101-W100DBD5B4851987FB2025EA9550@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY101-W100DBD5B4851987FB2025EA9550@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <e44a10180712281002m5d826673p8ee262d5a16f1410@mail.gmail.com>

I had a friend help me make a duct tape dummy head. It has been
discussed a few times in the fursuit LJ community. There are some
How-To's out there, but I'll go over how mine was made.
Having someone help you is a must. Beyond the dangers of suffocation,
doing such work on your own head would be close to impossible.
I started with a balaclava on my head, my hair completely tucked
underneath it. Then, my friend wrapped my head in cellophane, leaving
my nostrils uncovered so I could breath. Once my head was wrapped and
the cellophane was sticking to itself, he begin placing strips of duct
tape on the cellophane, none on the balaclava. To give the duct tape
head some structure, he started with a band of duct tape around my
crown, like a sweat band. Then a chin strap and pieces across the top
of my head. The pieces don't have to be terribly long, so they are
easier to shape to the contours of your head. Again, the bridge of
your nose can be covered but leave your nostrils uncovered. Once there
was a solid layer of duct tape around my head, he took a pair of cheap
child's safety scissors and cut the cellophane and duct tape. He
started from the back of my neck to slightly below the top of my head.
This allowed the duct tape and cellophane to be removed with out
damaging the balaclava. Don't worry about the cellophane, it can stay
attached to the duck tape head. Take off the balaclava, tape the cut
seam together, stuff the head with polyphil, then tape up the neck
hole.

I hope this helps,

-Tsuyoto

On 12/28/07, shane ramos <tsukasa06 at msn.com> wrote:
>
>       Whom ever that can help me some,
>
>  I'm about ready to take a stab at making a balaclava head, but my problem
> is: How can I make the 20.5" wigstand head match the 22" of my own head so
> this can turn out to fit me more than turn out to be a complete waste?
>
>  Thanks for the help,
>       ~Shadow-Da-Wolf

From pixie_da_dead_juggla at yahoo.com  Fri Dec 28 13:21:00 2007
From: pixie_da_dead_juggla at yahoo.com (Kit Kat)
Date: Fri, 28 Dec 2007 10:21:00 -0800 (PST)
Subject: FL: Balaclava question
In-Reply-To: <BAY101-W390679A51FC0E6A5403B50A9550@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <69639.17424.qm@web53808.mail.re2.yahoo.com>

I have worked only with balaclava heads so far and I would actually cut inch thick slabs of foam and duck tape it around the foam heads till I got a lil bit over the measurements of my head (Warning: do not compress the foam down, the foam will tend to try to expand and lift the duct tape up) Cuz when working with the balaclava has you fur it it will shape the head and reduce the stretch in the material which is why the zipper feature is very important otherwise you can't put it over your head...I have also used thick ace bandages for small alterations in size and duct tape over cuz the glue sometimes goes through depending on what fabric the balaclava is made of. 

shane ramos <tsukasa06 at msn.com> wrote:    .hmmessage P { margin:0px; padding:0px } body.hmmessage { FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY:Tahoma }   I'll keep this in mind if my help would like to try this... but I already have a stand that I plan to work with...

> doing such work on your own head would be close to impossible.

> underneath it. Then, my friend wrapped my head in cellophane, leaving

> head some structure, he started with a band of duct tape around my
> crown, like a sweat band. Then a chin strap and pieces across the top
> of my head. The pieces don't have to be terribly long, so they are
> easier to shape to the contours of your head. Again, the bridge of
> your nose can be covered but leave your nostrils uncovered. Once there
> was a solid layer of duct tape around my head, he took a pair of cheap
> child's safety scissors and cut the cellophane and duct tape. He
> started from the back of my neck to slightly below the top of my head.
> This allowed the duct tape and cellophane to be removed with out
> damaging the balaclava. Don't worry about the cellophane, it can stay
> attached to the duck tape head. Take off the balaclava, tape the cut
> seam together, stuff the head with polyphil, then tape up the neck

From furrycouple at hotmail.com  Sat Dec 29 12:56:25 2007
From: furrycouple at hotmail.com (Johara Saluki)
Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2007 15:56:25 -0200
Subject: FL: Balaclava question
In-Reply-To: <BAY101-W100DBD5B4851987FB2025EA9550@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY101-W100DBD5B4851987FB2025EA9550@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <BAY109-W16680AAEEB2702052B223BA5560@phx.gbl>


Here's how I made a life cast of my head. Using duct tape may not be as rigid as you like. Go to a hobby/craft store and ask for plaster gauze. This is wonderful stuff. You cut it into strips, dip in water, then cover the desired surface. This stuff will harden in about 15 minutes giving you a rigid mold. If you put this on your head and you have hair, be sure to use a plastic bag fitting tightly so as to retain as much of your nature shape. For your face, use vaseline on eyebrows and such....clean shaven works best for the rest. Only make a mold of half your head (side to side) at a time, or you will have a heck of a time cutting it off. Use the gauze at the end to join the two halves together. For me, I had two part polyeurothane expanding foam. I filled the mold with this, let it set then peeled the gauze off. Now I had a life cast of my head that I could pin to. If you go this route, don't use 'Great Stuff' foam. This requires porosity to allow the solvents to evaporate from the foam. The plaster gauze does not breathe. If you use the balaclava on your head for all of this, it may add thickness making the mold bigger. 
Keep in mind, the gauze will stick to hair (voice of experience) so cover or coat it. This is a little more work than the tape, but the result is a more sturdy form. 
Good luck. I'm about ready to take a stab at making a balaclava head, but my problem is: How can I make the 20.5" wigstand head match the 22" of my own head so this can turn out to fit me more than turn out to be a complete waste? Thanks for the help,     ~Shadow-Da-Wolf

From wonder_moose_blue at yahoo.com  Sat Dec 29 20:45:55 2007

Wrap the wig stand head with polyester batting until you get the volume you need. Then cover that with a plastic shopping bag and tape it down to conform.

From bob at ginkosoft.com  Sat Dec 29 23:54:31 2007
From: bob at ginkosoft.com (Bob Bauhaus)
Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2007 20:54:31 -0800
Subject: FL: Balaclava question
In-Reply-To: <BAY101-W95730B34665902FC900DEA9570@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY101-W100DBD5B4851987FB2025EA9550@phx.gbl>
	<BAY101-W95730B34665902FC900DEA9570@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <1198990473.22DE96C@bb11.dngr.org>

> where could I find the polyester batting at?

Most crafts and fabrics stores will have them. It's the stuffing used in 
quilts. So wherever you're getting your fur from.

In short, use the duct tape to rough out a shape, use the styrofoam head 
to give it a way to mount and solidity, and stuff with padding or 
batting to fill in the difference.

-BobCoon
